close_symbols: (any size constants used by the above structs, e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or similar)
explanation:
To determine whether the memset/strncpy calls can access out-of-bounds memory you must know the actual object layouts and sizes and how the source string is stored:

- OS_condvar_prop_t: needed to know sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t) (used in memset) and, crucially, the size of condvar_prop->name (the destination length used in strncpy). This determines the value of sizeof(condvar_prop->name) - 1 used as strncpy length.

- OS_common_record_t: needed to know the type and storage of record->name_entry (the strncpy source) and the size of that storage (if it is an array). If name_entry is a char array its size must be compared against the strncpy length; if it is a char * the allocation/ownership semantics must be known to judge whether reading up to the strncpy length can exceed the source object.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: this macro/function maps the token to a record pointer. You must inspect this to confirm that the returned record pointer actually points into OS_global_condvar_table records (so the record->name_entry buffer's size and lifetime are as defined by OS_common_record_t) and that no additional indirection or packing changes sizes.

- OS_global_condvar_table: the table definition may determine the record layout, alignment, or any custom sizing for name buffers; examining it ensures the record returned by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET has the expected storage for name_entry.

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: inspect this macro to confirm it only tests for NULL (or similar) and does not perform any additional bounds/size validation. This affects whether the memset of the whole OS_condvar_prop_t is guaranteed safe with respect to the pointer passed in.

- (any size constants used by the above structs, e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or similar): struct field sizes are often defined via macros/constants. You need those constants to compare source and destination buffer sizes numerically.

With these symbols you can determine: 1) the destination buffer length used by strncpy, 2) the actual allocated size of the source buffer (record->name_entry), and 3) whether memset writes the full object size safely. Those facts are required to assess compliance with the MISRA C rule about string functions not accessing beyond object bounds.
